Speaker: Sir JOHN FORREST
Title: ALLOTMENTS
text: Swan-Trea surer) [3.48] - I move-s That this Bill be now read a second time. As honourable - members are aware, this a war-time profits Bill , not a War Profits Bill . It is a measure based, not upon profits made from the war, but upon profits made during the war-eve n those per cent. increased profits which have not necessarily resulted from the war itself. A war-time profits tax was first imposed by the Britisli Government by the Finance Act No. 2 of 1915. It applied to profits shown in all accounts made up after 4th August, 1914. The tax imposed for the first year was 50 per cent, of the amount - by which those profits .exceeded the pre-war standard of profits, the pre-war standard being tihe greater of the follow(Queensland), ing sums:-(a ) The average profits of the best two out of the last three pre-war (Victrade years, or (b) 6 per cent, (in the case of a company) or 7 per cent, (in other businesses). The last pre-war trade year is similar to that fixed under the Bill now before the House, in clause 15 The revenue collected from this tax in the first year of assessment - was approximately £86,000,000. The Finance Act No. 3 of 1916 increased the rate of 6th tax for the second year to 60 per cent., and the revenue was in the region of £140,000,000. The Finance Act 1917, passed i u March, 1917, increased the rate to 80 per cent, of the excess profits, and the Chancellor of the Exchequer estiIN - REPL Y. mated the revenue at about £200,000,000 just received for the year 1917-18. Canada was the next part of the Empire to impose a war-time profits tax. In 1916 the Canadian Parliament passed the Business Profits War Tax Act, which imposed a tax of 25 per cent, on all busiprofits exceeding 7 per cent, on the This Act applied retrospectively to all business profits arisExing in accounting periods ending after 31st December, 1914. The revenue from Adthe tax on the first taxable year's profits of was £2,500,000, while the total amount deexpected to be collected for that year was of £3,000,000. The revenue estimated for exthe three years of the currency of the Act was £5,000,000, but the estimate for the second year , alone is £4,000,000 or more. On the 18th May, 1916, the rates of tax were amended to apply to profits arising in accounting periods ending after 31st December, 1916, by providing that the tax of 25 per cent, should apply to all profits over 7 per cent, and not exceeding 15 per cent.; on the part of the profits is over 15 per cent, and not exceeding fiO per cent, the rate was increased to 50 per the cent.; and on all the part of the profits the exceeding 20 per cent, the rate was 75 Under the Canadian law a business cannot take its actual pre-war profits as the pre-war profits standard. All businesses which have made a profit of more than 7 per cent, on capital in any war time accounting period must pay tax on the excess of the profit over 7 per cent. Whilst the Canadian scheme attains simple and economical administration and a large revenue, it acts unjustly on those businesses which have not made greater profits during the war-time year, or whose profits have actually diminished owing to the war but are still in excess of 7 - per cent, on capital. The Dominion of New Zealand followed with its tax, but imposed ib by way of additional income tax. The tax is 45 per cent, of the amount by which the income assessable to income tax in the war-time accounting period exceeds the average yearly assessable income of the last three pre-war trade years, or the average yearly assessable income of any shorter pre-war business period, or 7 per cent, on the capital employed in the business, whichever is the greater. The Prench Parliament has lately passed a war-time profits tax. The latest information available shows that there are two classes of taxpayers-on e paying a tax of 50 per cent, of the net profits in excess of the pre-war standard of profits, or 10 per cent, on capital, whichever is the greater; and the other paying the same rate of tax but receiving a general exemption of £ 2 0 0 . I now come to the Bill before the House. The Bill is modelled upon the English law, but it contains many additional provisions designed to render the incidence of the tax more equitable. This Bill taxes the excess profits of all businesses of any description carried on in Australia-and Australia includes - Papua - except those which are specially exempt by section 8. Under these provisions a business which balances on, say, 31st July in each year, will pay its first tax on the excess profits arising in the accounting period ending on 31st July, 1915. business which balances on 30th June in each year will pay its first tax on the excess profits arising in the accounting period ending on 30th June, 1916. the former case the business begins to pay tax eleven months earlier than in the latter case. In order thab when the Act terminates these two businesses may be fairly treated?- clause 2 will require the Sir John Forrest. business balancing on 30th June to pay .tax on profits arising for eleven months after the former business has ceased to pay tax. This is fair, because it began to pay tax eleven months after the other business. For example, assuming that peace is declared in May, 1918, the accounting period of company " A " ends on 31sb Jul y in each year. The accounting period of company " B " ends on 30th June in each year. Company " A " will pav tax on profits earned in the years ending 31sb July, 1915; 31st July, 1916; 31st July, 1917; 31sb July, 1918. Company " B " will pay tax on profits earned in the years ending 30th June, 1916; 30th June, 1917; 30th June, 1918; 30th June, 1919. Where an 'accounting period for which the tax is to be assessed is less than a year, the amount of the pre-war standard of profits is to be proportionately reduced, so thab a comparison of profits for a similar pre-war and post-war period .will be possible. Before any business is taxed under this Bill , its war-time profits must exceed the pre-war standard of profits. When the excess is nob greater than £200, no tax will be payable. When it is greater than £200, a deduction will be allowed of £200, reduced by £ 1 for every £ 2 by which such excess is greater than £ 2 0 0 . This means that ibhe deduction of £200 disappears entirely when the war-time profits are £600 or more in excess of the pre-war standard of profits. Speaking generally,- every business will retain out of its profits an amount equal to its pre-war profits, or the statutory percentage on its capital, whichever is the greater, plus the untaxed residue of the excess profits remaining to the taxpayer. The basis of the tax is the amount by which the pro-fibs of the war-time accounting period exceed the pre-war standard of pro fits. The pre-war standard of profits is to be the actual neb profits based on the average of any two of the last, three pre-war trade years, unless those years have been years of abnormal depression, in which case any two of the preceding three A pre-war years is taken for purposes of the average for comparison with the profits of the accounting period. If these actual profits are less than 10 per cent, on the In average capital employed in the selected two pre-war years, 10 per cent, on that capital is taken as the pre-war standard of profits. Ten per cent, is considered a fair percentage standard for invesbments in Australia. In the case of new businesses ancr businesses which have only become profit earning since the war, the Bill empowers the Commissioner of Taxation to increase that percentage if it is shown that the' increase is essential to insure the financial stability of the business. If the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the decision of the Commissioner in such a case, be can appeal to a Board of Referees for a final decision. 2\Tew businesses commenced by individuals or by partnerships will receive 'a further concession in the shape of an allowance of at least £300 as salary to the individual owner, and to each of the partners, provided in each case the owner and the partners devote the whole of their time to the business. In the case of a partnership in which some of the partners cannot devote the whole of their time to the business, a deduction of a proportion of the £300 allowance is to be deducted in respect of the part of the time given to the business. In the case of new companies the Bill limits the remuneration of directors to £1,000. This provision was copied from the New Zealand Act, except that the deduction has been reduced from £1,500 to £1,000. It is a very necessary provision to prevent the absorption of profits of new companies by way of directors' fees.. Provision has been inserted in the Bill empowering the Commissioner to increase any of these allowances if special circumstances exist to justify the increase. It is considered thab these provisions amply protect new businesses, and secure equitable treatment for them. In the case of old businesses the preproper war remuneration to partners, managers, or directors is allowed by the Bill , but under clause 14 (7) the Commissioner power to increase the allowance owing any special circumstances or to the fact that the remuneration depends on the profits of the business. The tax will apply to persons earning commissions to the profits of agents of any description, not being a commercial traveller or an agent whose remuneratjon consists wholly of a fixed and definite sum.not dependent on the amount of business done or any other contingency. The Bill provides in section 2 that last profits to be taxed are those arising up to the end of the accounting period tions ending after 30th June next after the claration of peace in ' connection with present war. The exempt businesses are described in clause 8 as follows:(a) Businesses carried on by a municipal corporation or. other local governing body or by a public authority; or by a society registered under a Friendly Societies Act of the Commonwealth or State or Territory, and not carried on for pecuniary profit; or by a religious, charitable, or public educa< tional institution; or any company, carrying on the business of life insur- ance so far as regards its life insurance business; and (6) agriculture, fruit-growing, the maintenance of dairy herds for the supply of dairy products, and (where conducted on land first used for pastoral purposes since the beginning of the present war) pastoral pursuits; and (c) offices or employments; and (d) any profession the profits of which depend mainly on the personal qualifications of the person by whom it is carried on, and in which comparatively little or no capital expenditure is re1 quired; and (e) businesses where the principal business consists of mining for gold; and (/) businesses commenced since the 4th day of August, 1914_, which, in the. opinion of the Commissioner, derive the whole of their profits from the recovery from waste manufactured products of any materials which are used for the production of munitions of war. The exemptions are limited to the callings and businesses exempted,' and do not extend to any other person who may subsequently trade in the goods produced by the exempt persons. The tax is limited to the profits of businesses carried on in Australia. It is that the country from which profits are derived should have the first righ t to levy taxes on that profit. The Act will has not, therefore, apply to any business to whose operations - are carried on outside Australia, - although the owners of the business may reside in Australia, unless the produce of the business is sold in and Australia. These remarks apply to mining and rubber companies whose mines and plantations are outside Australia, but the produce of which is sold in Australia. In regard to the calculation of profits and deductions, the war-time profits are to be ascertained for the purposes of the Bill in similar manner to the taxable income for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There are, however, special deducallowed by this Bill - for example, dedeductions for repairs deferred owing to the the war; for exceptional depreciation or obsolescence of plant and maohinery due to the war; and other matters mentioned in clause 10. Clause 14 of the Bill provides that all rates and taxes, including Federal and State land and income taxes, and war-profits tax paid on the profits in anycountry outside the Commonwealth, may be deducted from the war-time profits. The war-profits tax itself is not a deduction, but is deductible from taxable in come for purposes of income tax, and the Bill authorizes the Commissioner to adjust past income tax assessments so as to deduct the war profits tax from the taxable income which has formed the basis for the war-profits tax. These provisions are to be found in clause 14 sub-clauses 3 and 4. Wasting assets are dealt with in clause 3-for definition-and clause 14; subclauses 5 and 6. The Bill recognises the necessity for permitting businesses employing wasting assets to retain sufficient profits to recoup capital expended on those assets. " Wasting assets " is defined in clause 3 of the Bill as follows: "Wasting assets" means mines (other than coal mines), quarries, timber rights, and any similar asset which, through gradual removal of the substance used becomes exhausted. ' Coal mines have not been included in this provision, because they are not in the same class as metal mines, which have a very limited life. A coal miue is generally regarded as a comparatively fixed and lasting asset. This principle, altered to suit the circumstances, has been extended to leaseholds. All these provisions will be found in Part IV . , clause 14, sub-clauses 5 and 6. Allowance is made in clause 11 (1) of the Bill for exemption on account of natural growth' of. a business. Natural growth is based on the amount of additioual capital invested in the business. Accumulated profits invested in the business are treated as capital. The measure of the natural growth of a business is, the statutory percentage on the additional capital, or, the average rate of profits of the pre-war trade years-selecte d for tihe pre-war profits standard-o n the new capital, whichever is the greater; and this amount is to be deducted from the war-time profit before the taxable excess profits are assessed. If the capital of a business has been reduced by withdrawal during the wartime period, a proper comparison Sir John Forrest. * the pre-war - profits is only possible by adding to the actual profits the statutory percentage or the average rate of pre-war profits on the amount of capital withdrawn from the business, calculated for the period during which it was withdrawn - This provision will not apply in cases where capital is lost owing to losses by fire, flood, drought, &c. The accounts of each business are to be assessed separately, but if one person carries on a number of businesses, and makes an excess profit i h one and a loss in another, he can deduct the net loss from the excess profits. The Bill provides in clause 14, subclause 11, that where a business has sustained a net loss on its trading since the beginning of the first pre-war trade year and up to the commencement of the accounting period on which it is being taxed, any part of the profits of the taxable accounting period may be appropriated to recoup that net loss, the amount so appropriated being deducted from the taxable profits in ascertaining the amount liable to tax. The Bill harmonizes with the Income Tax Assessment Act , and each year's profits will be assessed separately and without regard to the trading results of any other war-time year, except as regards past losses which have not been fully recouped from subsequent profits. As already stated, these are deductible from the assessable profits. Under clause 14, sub-clause 9, a deduction will be made when ascertaining profits of any sums set apart by employers for profit sharing with employees so far as such profits have been distributed to the employees within six months after the close of the business year or such furthe r time as the Commissioner may allow. Capital is-dealt with in clause 16. The amount of the capital of a business is the capital paid up by the owner whether in money or in kind, together witli all accumulated profits invested in the business with the addition or subtraction of balances brought forward from previous years to the credit or debit respectively of profit and loss account. Assets acquired otherwise than for cash or credit, or acquired without purchase, are to be valued at the time of acquisition, and that value is to be treated as part of the capital of the business: Patents and with secret processes are deemed to be material assets to be valued in the manner mentioned. I come now to the provisions with regard to the recovery of the tax. B i ll contains wide powers for recovery of the tax. Under clause 13 the person for the time being owning or carrying on the business or acting as agent for another person carrying on the business may be assessed for the tax. text: Balaclava-Minister for Works and Railways) [4.33] - I move That this Bill be now read a second time. This Bill is rendered necessary by the probable early completion of the transcontinental railway. The railways of the Commonwealth, when that line is complete, will comprise three different lines. The first is the transcontinental railway, of 1,052 miles, stretching from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie; the second, the Port Augusta to Oodnadatta narrow gauge- 3 f t . 6 in - line , of 478 miles; and the third, the Port Darwin to Katherine line, which, when completed, as it will be shortly, will be 200 miles in length. We thus have a total of 1,730 miles of line which, by the end of September, we think, will be in operating condition, and under the control of the Commonwealth. Up to the present,- these lines have been operated in three different ways. The broad gauge line, during the course of construction, has been operated by the Minister under the powers conferred by the Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie Railway Act; the Oodnadatta line has been operatedby the Government of South Australia under the acquisition agreement, and the Port Darwin to Katherine line has been operated under territorial regulations in connection with the Department of Home and Territories. This Bill will bring all these lines under uniform control. ' It represents the first attempt to provide a Commonwealth procedure and policy of railway management, and in that regard I am sure honourable members will carefully scan its provisions. There are no politics, properly so-called, in the Bill; but there are some very, definite principles. The chief of these is thati this Bill makes for non-political control By pily, we have not to invent any system of running railways for the Commonwealth, because we have for our guidance the experience of the six different States. The careers of those State systems extend over upwards of two generations, and they have experienced the difficulties, the disabilities,- and the vicissitudes attaching to all great commercial undertakings. They have experimented with both political and non-political' control, and in every case T have settled upon non-political control as the more preferable. If I were to endeavour to anticipate the feeling of the people of Australia, I should say that, if consulted, they would certainly express a preference for such a system of control. This Bill, therefore, in its early clauses, provides for the appointment of a Railways Commissioner. His duties, powers, limitations, and relations to the Minister are clearly set out in those clauses, many of which are adapted, and many more borrowed from existing State railway statutes.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Title: ALLOTMENTS
text: East Sydney) [9.45] The question of the treatment to be meted out to our returned soldiers should so far command the respect of the House of There Representatives that a greater number of honourable members should be present while it is under consideration. I think we should have a quorum present. [Quorum formed.] Questions affecting returned soldiers should command more I attention from honourable members than is evidenced by the present state of the House. In my opinion, the Bill will be useless, and has been introduced merely to justify speeches made by members of the Ministerial party. I am the more convinced of that because the honourable memWe ber for Parkes, who graces the House .with his bulky presence, speaking in defence of the Government proposal, said that it might be of some service, but that.the public had a short memory, and that it would be two years and ten months before another election would take place. I regard the Bill as merely an effort to delude those noble and grand fellows who have done so much for Australia's fame. Many returned soldiers come to my house and complain of the treatment they have received since their return, though I have not voiced some of these complaints, because I think that at a time like this nothing should be done to prejudice recruiting. But if Ministers were in earnest they would see that returned men were better "treated. I do not blame the Postmaster-General personally for the cases that I am about to relate, because I do not know that he is aware of the facts. But I blame his Department. These oases were brought under my notice by members of the Ministerial party. One of them is that of a young fellow who was given employment at the General Post Office, Sydney, and, after working there for three or. four months, had a relapse, and was advised by his doctor to spend a few days in bed. When he returned to his duty, his superior officer said to him, " You have been away for two days. You must send in your resignation." He replied, " I will see you damned first.!' He is a true Australian, with sufficient backbone to resist tyranny, and would not be set aside in that way, and I counselled him not to resign. Finally he was told that he would be no longer employed. The second case was that of a young returned soldier who was employed in the test room at the General Post Office, Sydney. It being whispered in his ear that he was to "get the run on Priday," he said, ' ' B y God, they are not going to run me without a reason," and he asked his superior officer whether he had not been doing his work properly during the six or seven weeks of his employment. The superior officer said that he had been one of the best men that they had had, but, on going to a second official, the returned soldier was told that he was filling the place of a married woman who had been absent on holidays. Thereupon he saw the head official, who said to him, " I do not know a word about this." Notwithstanding those cases, we have instances of men being employed in the Public Service as temporary hands for over two years, and for a year and ten months. As to the prescribed examination, I do not know whether other, members have had experience similar to my own, but I have had examination papers brought to me. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Wimmera only a few minutes ago, many of our returned soldiers will probably possess only the ordinary public-school standard of education. absolutely farcical to require a man forty-five years of age, who probably left school when he was only twelve years old, to submit himself to an examination, in order to determine his fitness for admission to our Public Service. I have Mr West. seen many examination papers which it would be impossible for students, even from high schools, to answer satisfactorily. Some of the questions put to the candidates are not test questions at all. I can recall the case of one lad of fourteen years of age, who was asked to say what was the reason for the failure of Sir John Robertson's Land Bill. There is nothing in this Bill which will benefit our returned soldiers to any appreciable extent. As a matter of fact, the Public Service Commissioner is already in a position to do more for our returned soldiers than can be accomplished under this measure. When the members of the Government occupied seats upon this side of the chamber, they incessantly prated about the need for economy. Now they propose the stoppage of practically all the public works, and the displacement of a large body of men. Under this measure the number of returned soldiers who will gain admission to the Commonwealth Service will be very limited indeed. As a matter of fact, a large proportion of them, owing to the strain and stress of war, will be quite incapable of filling many of the positions in our Public Service. We know, too, that, after having had experience of a soldier's life, they will be very averse to following any sedentary occupation. The Bill; I repeat, is valueless, and I would strongly counsel the Government to lay it on one side. Let the House bear in mind that the reason why a large number of the best officers are working under temporary conditions is that they could not pass the puzzle put before them as an examination. These tests were intentionally designed ,to block the men. The Government say that they are not increasing the Public Service, but are merely taking on men for temporary purposes. I often think that if the public had an idea of the subterfuges which are put before them they would ask: What are our members of Parliament made of T In this measure there is no honest inIt is tention on the part of the Government to help returned soldiers. It has only been brought into delude the public into thinking that the intention is to win the war and to indicate that they are trying to help returned soldiers. If it is passed it will prove to be a stumbling block on the statute-book. What I am striving to impress upon the Government, if I can only instil the idea into their brains, is the need to do something of a substantial character for the returned men. If they were so disposed, they could find employment at once; but this Bill will not give a job to one man who comes back from the war. I call upon the Government to do what the people of Australia put them in power to do, and, if they are not ready to proceed, to make way for honourable members on this side. When we are dealing with matters of this kind we must be candid, and not mealy-mouthed. It is the duty of this side to point out to the House the real position. I am not bustling to get over to the other side. I think it is pleasant to be a member of the Opposition, because sometimes one can give expression to his feelings and thoughts, and point out the wrongs of humanity. The wrongs from which humanity and the soldiers are suffering have compelled me to feel stern on this occasion, and urge the House to take some action on behalf of the returned soldiers. I know that there is no man in Australia who has so much on his shoulders, and who is so anxious to do all the work that requires to .be done as is the Prime Minister; but when we glance over from this side we see a number of men on the other side who offer very little assistance to the right honourable gentleman. I hope that the Government will be a little more earnest than they have been. I am sure that they have not given to this measure the consideration which they ought to , have given. It will not, I repeat, give a tion to one returned soldier. Even if the Government decide that .public servants of military age,' and not married, should go to the war, it will be a very small centage who will leave the Public Service. If the Government are in earnest in this matter, they need not wait for the passage of this Bill. I believe that the desire of the people of Australia is that returned soldiers should be given the advantages which are extended to men who have not been soldiers, and should not be subjected to a fanciful examina- , tion. The Prime Minister knows what is going on. He is not so dull as he appears to be, but he has to do something now [18] to deceive the gentlemen who are calling upon him to move. If it is not what the people of Australia intended should be done, our criticisms are quite justified, because, although few in number, we represent over 1,000,000 of the adult inhabitants of the Commonwealth. We have a right, therefore, to point out the dangers of the path which the Government are treading, with the view to their carrying out the wishes of the people. Every member of this House is anxious to do what he can for our brave boys, and the country is behind us, but this measure will not do what the Government want to do or what the people wish to be done. Por the edification of the Prime Minister I will cite the cases of two soldiers. One case is that of a returned soldier who was employed in the Post Oflice for three or four months. He was sick for a time, and later he had a relapse. He went to see a doctor, who advised him to go into Rose Hall, in Forbes-street, Darlinghurst, for a few days. When he went back to the Post Office he reported that the doctor had advised him to go into a hospital for a short time. The officer said to him' " You have been away for two days, and you will have to send in your resignation." The returned soldier replied, " I will do nothing of the kind.
